awd_titl_txt: Extreme and Singular Behavior in Fundamental Models of Fluid Mechanics
awd_abstract_narration:
This mathematical research project will develop and apply theoretical and computational tools to systematically search for extreme behavior in solutions of some of the fundamental equations of fluid mechanics. The goal is to derive precise predictions of physically significant quantities from first principles and understand the underlying nonlinear dynamical mechanisms. The work capitalizes on recent developments of the Principal Investigator, collaborators, and other scientists to implement ideas from optimal control theory and the calculus of variations to find flows achieving maximal mixing, optimal transport, or other extreme dissipation. Transport, mixing, and dissipation are among the most fundamental features of fluid flows and they are of foundational significance for important applications ranging from microfluidics engineering to climate science and astrophysics. The control and optimization techniques adopted here constitute novel computationally aided analysis approaches to these problems. This project directly involves advanced training for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers under the Principal Investigator?s direction at the University of Michigan.

The research is centered on studies of qualitative and quantitative properties of solutions of partial differential equations in fluid mechanics including the Navier-Stokes and advection-diffusion equations. The investigator employs modern applied analysis and scientific computation in collaboration with graduate students and postdoctoral researchers at the University of Michigan, and with other researchers elsewhere. The four major components of the work are: (1) to study qualitative and quantitative properties of solutions to advection-diffusion equations and determine limits on mixing in terms of features of the stirring flows with an ultimate goal of understanding mixing effectiveness of turbulence; (2) to utilize new optimization schemes to investigate extreme time averages in nonlinear dynamical systems and investigate their implications for classical models of Rayleigh-B?nard convection; (3) to implement computational optimal control methods to search for maximal enstrophy production in the three-dimensional Navier-Stokes equations; and (4) to apply the analysis and computation techniques to other nonlinear and/or stochastic dynamical models from interdisciplinary applications in biology, chemistry and physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project involved mathematical and computational studies of fundamental mechanisms of fluid transport, dissipation and mixing. New physical properties of these flows were discovered and analyzed.

For example, new bounds on optimal flows were discovered for heat transport between solid boundaries in 2D buoyancy-driven Rayleigh-Bénard convection. Steady and unsteady coherent flows were investigated. For unsteady flows, estimates of long-time averages of heat transport were calculated and used to investigate how transport by steady coherent flows compares with transport by turbulent convection.

A shell model was used to explore the long-term behavior of optimal mixing with a fixed energy budget. New methods for computing sharp estimates on time averages for solutions of nonlinear dynamical systems were developed. Another line of approach studied optimal mixing by fluid flows and developed theoretical results based on numerical solutions.

Results from these studes form the basis for further understanding of these complex nonlinear processes relevant for applications in engineering, geophysical and astrophysical fluid dynamics, and climate science. Outcomes from the invesigations were presented in research seminars and conferences and published in refereed scientific literature including Journal of Fluid Mechanics, Journal of Nonlinear Science, Physical Review Letters, Physics Letters A, Physica D and SIAM Journal on Applied Mathematics.

This project also supported the research of graduate students performing doctoral dissertation research and postdoctoral researchers at the University of Michigan.
